Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Advancing Space Sciences through Undergraduate Research Experiences (ASSURE)
Award.AbstractNarration: The Advancing Space Sciences through Undergraduate Research Experience (ASSURE) program at the University of California Space Sciences Laboratory provides undergraduate students with an immersive experience in space science research and engineering. Students are exposed to a multidisciplinary research laboratory setting, conducting cutting edge research alongside leaders in the field. The ASSURE program actively recruits participants from community colleges and other institutions serving populations historically underrepresented in the space and geosciences with the aim of providing research experience early in their careers. The interdisciplinary approach taken in the program is reflective of the range of skills that students may eventually face in the workforce.<br/><br/>The ASSURE program supports research projects relating to the development of spacecraft instrumentation and hardware, data analysis, and high performance computing at the forefront of federally funded geospace research. Students involved in the program acquire experience required for design and management of experimental research programs and support a range of on-going geospace missions. The research staff at SSL is composed of a diverse international community working on a range of space physics missions in radio astronomy, magnetospheric physics, heliophysics, planetary science, high energy astrophysics, and maintains robust engineering facilities. The range of work at SSL provides ASSURE students with the opportunity to gain a comprehensive exposure to a range of geospace research, including space weather and other phenomena of national importance. Students will receive a boot camps session in coding and professional development on communication skills including elevator pitches and presenting at a professional conference.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

The  Advancing Space Sciences through Undergraduate Research Experience (ASSURE) program is a Research for the Education of Undergraduates (REU) project at the University of California, Berkeley Space Sciences Laboratory. ASSURE aims to provide underserved students from community and junior colleges and first generation students with research experiences that support cutting edge projects and missions in the space and geo-sciences. The ASSURE program is an immersive ten week internship designed to recruit and support a diverse cohort of students from two-year institutions with the goal of retaining them in the space sciences. ASSURE aims to support early career research scientists in developing "best practice" mentoring techniques. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic the internship program was adopted to a virtual format using a mix of technological platforms.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

During the ten week program, students learned a range of skills relating to space and geoscience. Students learned a range of skills that allowed them to successfully integrate into a diversity of professional research groups: computer programming, reading scientific papers, and technology for data visualization. Students were also to communicate their research orally and create a scientific poster. Nine of the ten ASSURE students presented their work at a professional scientific conference.  One student co-authored a peer reviewed publication based on their participation in the program. Professional evaluation determined that the program was highly successful at meeting its goals.

 

Broader Impacts

 

This project provided an opportunity to recruit and retain fresh talent into the space sciences and engineering through supporting a diverse range of students from community colleges in a cutting edge research setting. All students were from community college students and only two students had parents with Bachelor level or higher education. These student participants in the program were given opportunities  to engage in real-world research that were not available at their home institutions. Evaluation showed that students reported significant gains in the extent to which their image of themselves and a STEM professional overlap. Many students remain involved in space and geosciences research after participation in the program.

 

The project provided training and support for research staff without regular pedagogical responsibilities to mentor undergraduate students. Mentors reported that they designed projects doable in two months by an undergraduate that addressed students interests and learning goals. Mentors described helping students pursue their interests and thinking about their transfer to a four-year institution. Many of the ASSURE staff and mentors were early career professionals, who benefitted significantly from both the programs professional development and mentor training curriculum. Mentors reported that their students are highly likely to pursue a 4-year STEM degrees and extended careers.
